channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for NY

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found wet. 1 container of Nu-Brite Coil Condenser Cleaner had a loose cap and leaked. Caps were then tightened and package was placed in protective bin. DescribePack: 1 container of Nu-Brite Coil Condenser Cleaner had a loose cap and leaked approximately 3 teaspoons worth of liquid. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The caps were tightened and package was placed in bin.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 07/27/2023 hidden dangerous goods were discovered during the shipment inspection process at the DHL Express LIC facility, located at 12-12 33rd Avenue, Long Island City, NY 11106. Transportation by road has been confirmed. Shipment also contains UN3480, Lithium ion batteries, Class 9 Single Package or Inner Packaging (if any): Packaging Type: Case Material of Construction: Plastic Package Capacity: 100 g Amount in Package: 100 g Number in Shipment 1 Number Failed: 1

  • Description: SequenceEvent: found the package on the floor leaking. looks like possible miss handling while unloading the package from trailer. DescribePack: glass bottle broken in half DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: used proper PPE and place the leaking package in a plastic container to mitigate the spill. use absorbent pads to clean up any spillage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: A white box of flammable liquid had yellow stains on one side and inside the box with a strong smell coming from it. It was originally wet at some point but dried quickly over time. DescribePack: One of the jugs had a loose cap which caused it to leak. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: I put it in a hazmat bag and brought it over to the hazmat cage with the fumes hud on.

item.title: Report X-2023070251
item.description:
Report X-2023070251

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-18T21:11:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-16
  • City: NEW YORK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Package was found brough to the attention of the spill specialist at one of our station locations in New York, NY. Part of a multi piece shipment, package was emitting a strong odor, however, a smudge of what looked like grey-green paint was seen on yellow tape on box. Package was opened at the request of Dangerous Goods Administration, and it was seen a green paint like substance had leaked in the package. Package was reported to contain a metal can which was bent and release an estimated 2 KG (L) of product. Bubble wrap was used to wrap the can and as dunnage. Originating in Hong Kong Paperwork traveling with the package indicated the package contained a waterproof coating which should have been milky white in color. However, the can inside stated the contents were "Xincaihong Special Ink" and was not the color the SDS indicated. Package was placed in a steel salvage drum and has been held at the station location pending FAA investigation.

item.title: Report I-2023060180
item.description:
Report I-2023060180

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-19T00:29:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-24
  • City: ORISKANY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HILLTOP ENERGY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 05/24/2023 while on a return trip from Heidelberg Materials in Jordanville, O'brien Brickey was traveling west on Rt. 5S toward Utica. As he crossed over a bridge he noticed material white in color coming out of the back of the truck(270). O'Brien pulled over immediately to check out the truck upon doing so noticed there was emulsion flowing out from what appeared to be several places. O'Brien immediately called his supervisor Derrick Paro who instructed him to call PERS and also NY DEC was notified. O'Brien was told by PERS that appropriate personnel would be dispatched for cleanup. The site was cleaned up and there is nothing further at this time.
